Award.AwardTitle: Chemical tools for capturing protein-protein interactions in live cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Just as humans use machines such as computers or cars to carry out complex tasks in day-to-day life, a cell uses many different kinds of machines to grow, to maintain its health, and to replicate. Unlike a computer or car, though, machines in the cell are often built only when needed for a particular task and are then disassembled; they are dynamic rather than static. An example of this is the machine that reads the information stored in DNA, the transcriptional machinery. More than fifty different proteins come together to form the transcriptional machinery at a specific gene and then the machinery is disassembled as the reading process begins. In part because they are short-lived, the interactions between proteins that comprise such machines are difficult to capture and visualize. This project focuses on developing novel tools such that dynamic machineries in the cell can be captured and studied in their native environment for the first time, tools that will be made available to the broader scientific community. The undergraduate students and graduate students working on this project will receive cross-disciplinary training in chemistry and biology and will share this knowledge in local Michigan K-8 classrooms.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Anna Mapp of the University of Michigan to develop novel strategies for the discovery and characterization of transient, modest affinity protein-protein interactions in the native environment of the cell. Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) underlie all cellular process, serving to localize chemistries to specific cellular locations in a time-dependent fashion. The variety of PPIs in terms of affinity and surface is astonishing, with strengths ranging from picomolar to millimolar and surface areas from <500 Å2 to >3000 Å2. PPIs with high affinity and small surface areas most resemble protein-ligand interactions and they are the most amenable to characterization by standard genetic and biophysical methodologies; not surprisingly, they are the most well-defined in terms of function and mechanism. However, many cellular machineries rely upon modest affinity PPIs to accomplish their function. Traditional genetic, biochemical and biophysical strategies for characterizing such interactions are often ineffective and PPIs that fall within the low affinity range are the most poorly characterized in term of structure and mechanism in addition to having the smallest number of small molecule probes available. The tools developed through this project will enable time-dependent capture of such PPIs through the site-specific incorporation of photoactivatable functional groups into one or more protein binding partners. Additionally, a comparison of distinct photocrosslinking functional groups across a continuum of protein-protein interfaces will be used to build a framework for experimental design targeting any PPI of interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Just as humans use machines such as computers or phones to carry out complex tasks in day-to-day life, a cell uses many different kinds of complex machines to grow, to maintain its health, and to replicate. Unlike a computer or car, though, machines in the cell are often built only when needed for a particular task and are then disassembled; they are dynamic rather than static. An example of this is the machine that reads the information stored in DNA, the transcriptional machinery. More than fifty different proteins come together to form the transcriptional machinery at a specific gene and then the machinery disassembles as the reading process begins. In part because they are short-lived, the interactions between proteins that comprise these machines are difficult to capture and visualize. This overall goal of this project was to develop novel tools such that dynamic machineries in the cell can be captured and studied in their native environment and to make those tools available to the broader scientific community.

 The tools that we developed are based on the natural amino acids that are the building blocks of proteins. Like the natural amino acids, the unnatural versions can be incorporated into proteins in the cell. In contrast to their natural counterparts, however, the unnatural versions undergo specialized reactions when the cells are irradiated with ultraviolet light. The reaction that we focused on was the ability of the unnatural amino acids to form very stable bonds with nearby binding partners. So, if we incorporated the unnatural amino acid into one of the building blocks of the transcriptional machinery, then we could shine light on the cell as the machine was being assembled and covalently capture the binding partners for identification and study. In doing so, we could then decipher the mechanism of how the machine is assembled.

The challenge we and others faced was that the light-initiated capture reaction was quite low yielding, making it technically challenging to isolate the captured proteins from the cell. Additionally, the capture reaction did not give any location information about where the proteins were interacting inside the cell. In the three years of this project, we addressed these challenges by developing several new versions of the unnatural amino acids that increased the yield of the covalent capture reaction or facilitated the isolation of the captured proteins by incorporating additional functionality into the structures. Furthermore, discovered a process called TRIC that allowed us to use the unnatural amino acid in combination with another chemical (formaldehyde) to pinpoint where in the cell a specific protein complex was being formed. This allowed us, for the first time, to determine a key protein-protein interaction that happens during the cell’s response to stress at the level of an individual gene. We found that one particular set of proteins, called transcription activators, use a specific combination of interactions to recruit a key player in the cell’s ability to respond to stress to genes and also to orient that key player so that it can carry out its functions. These interactions can now be manipulated to regulate stress response by cells and organisms, the focus of future studies in our group. The tools that we have developed have already been sent to labs across the US and internationally. In the last three months alone, we have provided reagents to four different laboratories for their studies on diverse cellular machines. 

The studies carried out during this grant period have made fundamental contributions to our understanding of how the transcription machine is assembled and provided materials, strategies and reagents that are now being used for an even broader range of studies in other research groups. We will continue to provide these reagents and expert assistance in the future. This project also lead to high-level training of five graduate students and three undergraduate students. These students have shared their knowledge and experience through activities at local K-8 schools and educational projects, including Females Excelling More in Math, Science and Engineering (FEMMES) at UM in which they designed and lead female elementary and middle school students in experiments at two capstone events each year.
